patterns: How to know if I have breast cancer?
responses: Common symptoms include a lump in the breast or underarm, changes in breast shape, dimpling of the skin, and nipple discharge.
Look for changes in breast size, texture, or pain in the breast or nipple. It's best to consult a doctor if you notice any unusual signs.
Breast cancer can be caused by genetic factors, hormonal changes, lifestyle choices, and environmental influences.
While the exact cause isn't always clear, factors like BRCA mutations, prolonged estrogen exposure, and age can increase the risk.

patterns: What are the stages of breast cancer?
Explain the stages of breast cancer
responses: Breast cancer is classified into stages 0 to IV, based on tumor size, lymph node involvement, and whether it has spread to other parts of the body.
Stage 0 indicates non-invasive cancer, while stage IV represents metastatic cancer that has spread beyond the breast.

patterns: What can I do to prevent breast cancer?
responses: Maintain a healthy lifestyle, exercise regularly, limit alcohol consumption, and avoid smoking.
Early detection through regular screenings and self-exams can also help in prevention and timely treatment.

patterns: Benefits of detecting breast cancer early
responses: Early detection significantly improves survival rates by identifying cancer before it spreads.
Treatments are often more effective and less invasive when breast cancer is caught early.

patterns: When should I get a mammogram?
responses: A mammogram is an X-ray of the breast used to detect abnormalities. It is recommended for women over 40 to have one annually.
Mammograms are key in detecting breast cancer early, often before symptoms appear.
